sub_title: Common Ground Dialogues, Regional Express, Rehearsing the Revolution, Own your Story; Depolarising and decolonizing narratives in co-creation
summary:
Petra Ardai is a theatre-maker, scenario writer, and science communication professional. She is the artistic director of the SPACE rooted in Amsterdam and Budapest. Petra's background is in documentary theatre. She creates immersive storytelling experiences in various media, like live games, interactive performances, multimedia installations, online art, heritage apps and podcasts. Petra is specialised in (future) scenario’s of radical changes and builds imaginary worlds around the question: ‘Who owns the Future?’ 
The narratives of the projects balance on the border between fiction and reality, making complex social issues relatable in an intensely intimate but playful manner. Topics such as polarisation, inequality, migration, unprocessed historical past and climate change are brought close through the politics of the personal. 
Petra collaborates with cross-sector partners from the field of art, science and NGO’s.
Petra is advisor at the Amsterdam Fund for the Arts (AFK), founding and board member of Plurality U+, a global diverse and open network to mobilise the resources of the imaginary to widen space of thinkable alternative futures.

authors.headline: Common Ground Dialogues, Regional Express, Rehearsing the Revolution, Own your Story; Depolarising and decolonizing narratives in co-creation

profile_positions.description:
In times of extreme polarisation, how do we still find a shared vision for the future? Stories makeup the world and people are storytelling machines 24/7. Over the next two years, in collaboration with the VU University Amsterdam and international partners, SPACE is developing and researching a storytelling format that brings people from diverse backgrounds into dialogue with each other around current polarising themes. Central to this is listening to the voice of the other, to people but also to other life forms such as the animals and landscapes around us. 
SPACE - Explorers of the Continuous Present is an internationally oriented art initiative, headquartered in Amsterdam. Based on the belief that art can question dominant narratives.
SPACE focuses on artistic, theatrical research into complex social issues. SPACE develops immersive, activist art experiences that bring together theatre, spoken word, experience design and visual art. 
Over the next two years, artistic director Petra Ardai and spoken word artist Jörgen Gario, together with artists, writers and activists in the Netherlands, France, Hungary and Slovakia, will produce story circles with young people, policymakers, prisoners, migrants, farmers, politicians and anyone who wants to lend an ear.
All the stories, conceived by different communities, will appear online, accompanied by drawings by Stella de Kort. VU University's Faculty of Social Sciences is conducting an impact study, the results of which will be published in late 2024.
For more information and news: www.spaceexplorers.nl
CGD is funded by Creative Europe and is a collaboration of:
We Are Space (NL), Vrije Universiteit (NL), Subjective Values Foundation (HU),Plurality University Network (FR) and Divadelná Nitra Festival (SL)
Associate partners: Tolhuistuin, Sztorimühely, Karrewiel, Climate CleanUp, Baltan Laboratories, FÜGE Productions, Plateau Urbain
profile_positions.title: Art Director at Common Ground Dialogues

profile_positions.description: “We believe that changes start from the inside and are convinced that co-creative art experiences can cultivate cultural shifts, make fundamental changes and collaborations possible even under circumstances when nothing else seems to work anymore."
profile_positions.title: Rehearsing the Revolution

profile_positions.description:
SPACE creates interactive documentary performances and immersive storytelling in diverse media. The projects are always culture specific and the participants or spectators are the main protagonists. The storytelling balances on the border of fiction and reality and dissects complex social issues like migration, polarisation, inequality, ownership, and colonisation through the politics of the personal. What if that would happen to you? What would you do in that situation? - the makers ask themselves and the audience. SPACE proposes that in the safe space of the imagination we can learn to express our fears and dreams and (re)connect to ourselves and each other. We can get a grip on reality by playing with fiction. 

https://www.spaceexplorers.nl
https://www.rehearsingtherevolution.org
https://oeduverse.eu

profile_positions.description: Digest The Future - visionary storytelling that brings people with various background together to imagine the future they want. Scientific knowledge meets life and unseen knowledge in artwork. We share food and stories. Digest The Future is immersive storytelling; words,  tastes, music, images and moves take us experiencing the imaginary as it is there. Where shall we start the change?
profile_positions.title: Digest The Future

profile_positions.location: Almere Corrosia, Rotterdam Maas, Amersfoorst Twijnstra Gudde, Parade Utrecht
profile_positions.description:
SOS EARTH – 99% resilient by SPACE explores the current fears around populism, identity and migration through an electrifying scenario.
SPACE’s documentary theatre style engages the audience in their performances.
For SOS EARTH – 99% resilient director Petra Ardai has chosen an extraordinary ‘what if’ narrative: The Earth is becoming uninhabitable and the human population is divided between Earth and Mars. SPACE and the public have to set up the first model colony on the red planet.
The theatre is the spaceship and the span of the performance covers 9 months, the time it takes to travel to Mars. The powerful video installation taking up the total width of the stage is an important element of SOS EARTH – 99 % resilient.
Eleven people, who in real life had to flee from their home countries and currently live in The Netherlands, reflect on fear and resilience in a striking kaleidoscope of personal experiences.
Ardai has assigned a special role to these eleven people in her dramaturgy: they are The Council, a group of experts with a true understanding of what it means to leave all what is familiar behind and face an unknown future. The Council supports the audience in their preparation, to become resilient for the upcoming ‘interplanetary human migration’, the new life ahead and the designing of a blueprint for a new, fair and sustainable society on the unknown planet.
While focusing on real, existing social issues SOS EARTH - 99% resilient evolves around hope.
On Mars humanity can reinvent itself. Humanity can make a step in the evolution and figure out how to shape this second chance.
„Who owns the future?“ is a relevant question that connects the fictitious and documentary line of the narrative. The emptiness of the red planet shows us that we need to be inclusive to be able to survive. Accordingly our dormant survival mechanisms, empathy or creative powers will reinvigorated and further developed.
profile_positions.title: SOS EARTH-99% resilient

profile_positions.description:
Wordt Mars straks een all-inclusive toevluchtsoord voor de rijke 1%? Of durven wij, de 99%, de stap te wagen naar een nieuw begin? SPACE is gevraagd om kwartiermaker te worden en vrijwilligers voor te bereiden op een reis naar het ultieme onzekere. We verruilen het lawaai van de Aarde om in kosmische stilte na te denken over hoe onze ideale wereld er eigenlijk uitziet. Experts met een vluchtelingenachtergrond geven tips en tools om ons hier doorheen te slepen.

SOS EARTH is een interactieve mockumentary theatervoorstelling, die op verrassende wijze reflecteert op populisme, angst en migratie. In dit ‘what if’ scenario worden de rollen omgedraaid. Door ons in te leven in de verhalen van vluchtelingen, trainen wij ons in weerbaarheid voor een intergalactische volksverhuizing. Live muziek vormt de playlist voor dit enkeltje naar Mars.
Theatermaker Petra Ardai, muzikant en dichter Jörgen UNOM Gario en de Syrische percussionist Modar Salama maken de playlist voor een enkeltje Mars.

Ook te zien als speciale versie op de Parade Den Haag, Utrecht en Amsterdam, juli - augustus 2017
Over het IJ festival, Amsterdam, 15 - 23 juli 2017 (première)
Stadsgehoorzaal Vlaardingen, 20 september 2017

On the 22nd and on the 24th of April TG Space will present Remember Amsterdam - CRASH COURSE REFUGEE # work in progress. Remember Amsterdam is an interactive documentary requiem with live music and video. Space zooms in on the refugee issue and shows Amsterdam through the eyes of natives and refugees.

24th April - 16h30

profile_positions.title: Remember Amsterdam / Crash Course Refugee

profile_positions.description:
STATS, your daily portion of truth is an interactive meeting point in the public space. 

We desperately try to capture our lives in numbers to have a better understanding of our world, but we rarely relate these data to our daily life or feel more interconnected by reading statistics. STATS is an interactive meeting point in the public space that shows the vibe of the (city) surroundings through real time statistics and invite the public to a dialogue.

In the press:  

"The documentary theatre of Stats is no doubt fascinating. The sheer numbers of  how much people drink, eat, spend on social media, transpire, visit prostitutes or are a prostitute, scam insurances, indulge on Facebook or visit dating sites is dizzying: sometimes the numbers go up to billions and they just keep on spinning. These 'real time statistics' have a beneficent effect on the audience: you realize that as an individual you are a part of this amazing machinery that is called humanity.(...)"

@Theaterkrant, July 2014

Concept: SPACE Text: Petra Ardai Research: Marike Splint  Dramaturgy: Anna Veress, Felix Ritter, Marike Splint Set- en graphic design: Rozi Szeleczki Data design en programming: Billy Schonenberg Sound and technical support: Luc van Loo Performers (additional moderation): Marta Pisco, Petra Ardai, Luc van Loo Management: Nora Duijf
STATS is a collaboration with the Rotterdamse Schouwburg for Imagine 2020. www.imagine2020.eu
profile_positions.title: STATS, your daily portion of truth

profile_positions.description:
The Plurality University Network is a global and open organization that connects artists, designers, utopians, activists and anyone wishing to expand and enable alternative futures imaginaries.

As climate emergency and “unimaginable” changes are about to impact the world in years to come, from which the confinement of half of the world’s population at the beginning of 2020 is a likely example, the urgency for humanity to reconsider its role as “masters and possessors” of nature seems unequivocal. But where to start? How to find tools and collective mechanisms to anticipate and adapt to transformations needed? To figure out novel directions for change, they need to be imagined: and the journey begins with individual and collective imaginaries.

In academia, the arts, politics, science, or grassroots movements, calls for “new narratives” and for the “renewal” or “liberation” of imaginaries express a shared intuition: that any significant transition towards different and hopefully better futures, requires the ability to question inherited meanings, values, representations and finalities, and imagine completely new worlds and new ways of functioning. The Plurality University Network works towards putting these intuitions into action by creating the conditions for the emergence of new imaginaries, alternatives for action, and common paths for future transitions.
